title: 112_hr2362
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS; PURPOSES." is a condensed summary of the section's title, findings, and purposes. The Act may be cited as the "Indian Tribal Trade and Investment Demonstration Project Act of 2011." Congress finds that barriers are hindering relationships between Turkish and Indian tribal communities, and aims to establish a project to remove these barriers. The "Indian Tribal Trade and Investment Demonstration Project Act of 2011" aims to remove barriers to trade and financial investment in Indian tribal economies, encourage commerce and economic investment by entities from Turkey, and strengthen Indian tribal economies to improve the standard of living of Indians. The "Indian Tribal Trade and Investment Demonstration Project Act of 2011" aims to remove barriers to trade and financial investment in Indian tribal economies, encourage commerce and economic investment by entities from Turkey, and strengthen Indian tribal economies to improve the standard of living of Indians. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "applicant" as an Indian tribe or consortium applying for the demonstration project, "demonstration project" as the authorized trade and investment project, "Indian tribe" as defined in the Federally Recognized Indian Tribe List Act, "participating Indian tribe" as selected by the Secretary, and "project" or "activity" as community, economic, or business development endeavors. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior in a development undertaking that contributes to carrying out a purpose under multiple Federal programs. SEC. 3. INDIAN TRIBAL TRADE AND INVESTMENT DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. The Secretary authorizes Indian tribes to participate in the "Indian Tribal Trade and Investment Demonstration Project" under the Department of the Interior. Tribal approval of leases for projects involving private entities from Turkey does not require Secretary approval. The Act allows for leases on Indian land in trust for up to 25 years, with options for renewal, as long as they are not for mineral exploration, development, or extraction, and are executed under tribal regulations approved by the Secretary. The Act allows for leases on Indian land in trust for up to 25 years, with options for renewal, for purposes such as business, economic development, public, educational, or residential purposes, grazing, and farming specialized crops with substantial land improvement investments. The Secretary must approve tribal regulations consistent with the Act and including an environmental review process. The proposed action involves identifying and evaluating significant environmental effects, informing the public for comments, and responding to relevant feedback before finalizing decisions. The participating Indian tribe or consortium must approve the lease. The Secretary has 120 days to review and approve or disapprove tribal regulations submitted, with written documentation provided for disapprovals. The deadline for review may be extended after consultation with the tribe or consortium. If a participating Indian tribe or consortium carries out a project funded by a Federal agency, they can use the agency's environmental review process instead of tribal review. The tribe must provide the Secretary with documentation of any leases executed under approved tribal regulations. The United States is not liable for losses in leases under this Act. The Secretary can enforce or cancel leases with Indian tribes. Interested parties must comply with regulations. An interested party can petition the Secretary to review compliance of tribal regulations approved under this Act. If violations are found, the Secretary can take necessary actions, including rescinding approval of the regulations. The Secretary can take action if violations of tribal regulations are found, including providing written notice of the violation and holding a hearing before any remedy is exercised. The Secretary can take action for violations of tribal regulations by providing written notice and holding an on-the-record hearing with a chance to cure the alleged violation. SEC. 4. SELECTION OF PARTICIPATING INDIAN TRIBES. During the first year after the enactment of this Act, the Secretary may select up to 6 Indian tribes or consortia from the applicant pool to participate in the demonstration project. Consortia can be formed by two or more Indian tribes. The applicant pool consists of tribes or consortia that request participation through official tribal action and demonstrate financial stability and management capability for the preceding 3 fiscal years. The Indian tribe or consortium must show financial stability and management capability by having no material audit exceptions in the required annual audit of self-determination contracts. SEC. 5. APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS, REVIEW, AND APPROVAL. An Indian tribe or consortium selected under subsection (a) may submit an application to the Secretary identifying activities, describing economic benefits, and gaining approval from the governing body within 90 days. Upon receipt of an application, the Secretary will notify the applicant in writing of the approval or disapproval. If the application is disapproved, the reasons will be provided, and the applicant can amend and resubmit the application. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The report should include an analysis of the economic benefits and consequences for participating Indian tribes, members, and surrounding communities from the demonstration project. Additionally, it should contain observations and recommendations to enhance the project's operation and outcomes.
